caption:
This photograph captures a scene likely set in an industrial or utility control room. The primary focus is on a man stationed at a large control panel filled with numerous illuminated buttons and switches, predominantly in red and blue. The man appears to be a worker, wearing a white safety helmet and a plaid shirt; he holds a clipboard, suggesting he is either monitoring the systems, performing an inspection, or recording data.

The control panel, which stretches across the right side of the photo, is well-lit by the indicators, emitting a blue glow that adds a cool tone to the scene. The left side of the background reveals a glimpse of an industrial setting with complex machinery and structures, partially visible and faintly illuminated by natural light, suggesting an open doorway or window.

The overall atmosphere of the photo is somewhat somber and focused, emphasized by the low lighting, which casts shadows on the man's face and creates an aura of concentration and seriousness in his environment. The lighting and the array of buttons create a striking contrast, giving the picture a technical, almost cinematic quality.
title: Precipitates are continuously monitored in this "bag house" control room at the union carbide ferro-Alloy plant.  Total annual emissions from the plant powerhouse and metallurgical furnaces dropped 97.7 percent from 1967 to 1975, from 113,252 to 2,649 tons annually.  A compliance schedule was reached between the company and the West Virginia air pollution control commission.  Epa stack sampled plant emissions while developing national new source performance standards.  (see fiche #141 to 146)
